facts.text: Patna High Court upheld the appellant's conviction under s. 353, Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the High Court of Patna upholding the appellants companyviction under s. 353, Indian Penal Code and the sentence passed against him.

facts.text: The facts are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which are number in dispute are as follows

facts.text: On the evening of October 29, 1957, Mr. Bhupendra Narain Singh paid a surprise visit to the shop of Hazari Lall Co. in Barah town to inspect books of accounts.

anchor.surface_text: On the evening of October 29, 1957, Mr. Bhupendra Narain Singh, Assistant Superintendent of Commercial Taxes, Patna Sadar circle, paid a surprise visit to the shop of Hazari Lall Co., in Barah town in order to inspect the books of accounts maintained by the shop.

facts.text: Mr. Bhupendra Narain Singh is Assistant Superintendent of Commercial Taxes, Patna Sadar circle.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bhupendra Narain Singh, Assistant Superintendent of Commercial Taxes, Patna Sadar circle,

facts.text: Appellant Hazari Lall was in the shop at the time of visit.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the appellant Hazari Lall was in the shop.

facts.text: Mr. Singh found two sets of account books kept in the shop.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Singh found that two sets of account books were kept in the shop.

facts.text: Mr. Singh took the account books and started looking into them.

anchor.surface_text: He took them up and started looking into them.

facts.text: Appellant snatched away both the books from Mr. Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Tile appellant snatched away both the books from him,

facts.text: Appellant passed the books to one of his servants who made them over to another servant on the upper floor.

anchor.surface_text: passed them on to one of his servants who made them over to another servant who was on the upper floor.

facts.text: Mr. Singh directed his orderly peon to recover the books.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Singh directed his orderly peon to recover the books.

facts.text: Peon was prevented by the appellant from going to the place where books were taken and scuffle ensued, tearing the peon's shirt.

anchor.surface_text: The peon was, however, prevented by the appellant from going to the place where the account books had been taken and in the scuffle which ensued between the two, the orderlys shirt was torn.

facts.text: Mr. Singh went to the police station to lodge a complaint.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Mr. Singh went to the police station to lodge a companyplaint.

facts.text: Appellant was brought to police station by the Sub-Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was brought there by the Sub-Inspector,

facts.text: Appellant tendered an apology in writing at police station.

anchor.surface_text: tendered an apology in writing and so Mr. Singh did number lodge a companyplaint.

facts.text: Mr. Singh did not lodge a complaint due to the apology.

anchor.surface_text: and so Mr. Singh did number lodge a companyplaint.

facts.text: Mr. Singh submitted a report in writing to the Superintendent of Commercial Taxes.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, submitted a report in writing to the Superintendent of Commercial Taxes.

facts.text: Superintendent reported the incident to Deputy Superintendent of Police.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintendent thereupon reported the incident to the Deputy Superintendent of Police

facts.text: First information report lodged on November 1.

anchor.surface_text: and eventually lodged a first information report on November 1.

facts.text: Commissioner is authorised by law to delegate inspection powers to subordinates.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the Commissioner is authorised by law to delegate his power to his subordinates

facts.text: Power delegated to Assistant Superintendent of Commercial Taxes.

anchor.surface_text: and it is number disputed that such power has been delegated to the Assistant Superintendent of Commercial Taxes.

holdings.text: The action of the appellant amounts to use of force as contemplated by s. 349, I. P. C.

anchor.surface_text: It would be clear from a bare perusal of the section that one person can be said to have used force against another if he causes motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion to that other. By snatching away the books which Mr. Singh was holding the appellant necessarily caused a jerk to the hand or hands of Mr. Singh in which he was holding the books.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Snatching books causes jerk/motion to the hand holding them and affects sense of feeling, fitting plain language of s.349.

holdings.text: The appellant's act must be held to amount to use of criminal force.

anchor.surface_text: To feel annoyed at this action of the appellant would be the natural reaction of Mr. Singh and, therefore, the appellants act must be held to amount to use of criminal force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intentional use of force without consent during lawful inspection naturally causes annoyance to public servant.

holdings.text: Conviction under s. 353, I.P.C. is sustainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Snatching constitutes criminal force to deter public servant from discharging inspection duty, as force and criminal force established.

holdings.text: Mr. Singh was lawfully entitled to inspect account books without permission; appellant had no justification to snatch them.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 2 of s. 17 of the Act provides that all accounts, registers and documents relating to stocks of goods or purchases, sales and deliveries of goods by any dealer and all goods kept in any place of business of any dealer shall at all reasonable times be open to inspection by the Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17(2) Bihar Sales Tax Act mandates openness to inspection at reasonable times; r.50 permits surprise visits; delegated power.

holdings.text: Merely holding books for perusal is not seizure under s.17(3) Bihar Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion merely holding books found lying in the premises for perusing them cannot properly be regarded as seizure because seizure implies doing something over and above holding an article in ones hand. According to the Shorter Oxford Dictionary seizure,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Seizure requires confiscation or forcible possession beyond mere holding for inspection; distinguishes Prahlad Ram case.

holdings.text: Prosecution under s.353 I.P.C. is not precluded by lack of sanction under s.26(2) Bihar Sales Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: IPC offence independent; prosecutorial discretion to charge graver general law offence without sanction; avoids unpunished grave acts.

holdings.text: Appellant's act amounts to obstruction punishable under s.26(1)(h) of the Bihar Sales Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Snatching prevents inspection, fitting obstruction definition; obiter as not charged under this section.

holdings.text: Snatching constitutes offence under s.353 I.P.C., not merely under Sales Tax Act; Sonelal Seth distinguished.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior case omits 'change of motion'; over-taxes ingenuity; general law applicable even if special law fits.

anchor.surface_text: Prahlad Ram v. State 1 . In that case account books had been seized by a Superintendent of Commercial Taxes from the premises of a dealer for the purpose of inspecting them and it was held that the seizure was illegal because he had number recorded in writing his reasons for making the seizure as required by sub-s.  3  of s. 17 of the Act. The dealer and some of his employees were convicted of an offence under s. 353, 1. P. C. The High Court acquitted them on the ground that they were entitled to use force as the search of the premises and the seizure of the books was illegal. That case is distinguishable from the present one.

precedents.cited_proposition: Seizure of account books by Sales Tax officer without recording reasons in writing under s.17(3) Bihar Sales Tax Act is illegal, entitling dealer to resist with force and leading to acquittal under s.353 IPC
precedents.cited_holding: the seizure was illegal because he had number recorded in writing his reasons for making the seizure as required by sub-s.  3  of s. 17 of the Act. The High Court acquitted them on the ground that they were entitled to use force as the search of the premises and the seizure of the books was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Sonelal Seth v. The State 1 . There the question which arose for consideration was whether an act of the kind proved in the case before us falls under s. 353, I.P.C., Das, J., who decided the case held that it does number. The reason given by him is that the definition Patna High Court, unreprted. of criminal force contained in s.353, I.P.C.shows that what is contemplated by the section is the use of criminal force to or against a person and number to an inanimate object.

precedents.cited_proposition: Snatching away account books from Sales Tax officer does not constitute use of criminal force under s.353 IPC as it is force to inanimate object not person
precedents.cited_holding: it does number [fall under s.353 IPC]. ... I doubt whether in the circumstances of this case it can be said that criminal force was used to the Inspector of Sales Tax. In my opinion, it would be over-taxing ingenuity to bring the act of the petitioner within the mischief of criminal force, as defined in section 350 of the Indian-Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: It would be clear from a bare perusal of the section that one person can be said to have used force against another if he causes motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion to that other. By snatching away the books which Mr. Singh was holding the appellant necessarily caused a jerk to the hand or hands of Mr. Singh in which he was holding the books.

We, therefore, dismiss the appeal. Along with this appeal Criminal Appeal No. 35 of 1961 was also heard and this judgment will govern the decision of that appeal also.
